prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1717-337
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the absorption lines of the following molecules toward J1717-337, a Galactic molecular absorption systems. The required sensitivity is 3.0 mJy per 1.5" beam and the requested velocity resolution for each molecule is shown in parentheses.
CCH(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) SiO(6-5): USB (0.65 km/s) H13CO+(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) HCO(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) H13CN(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) CS(5-4): LSB (0.69 km/s) c-HCCCH(3-2): LSB (0.69 km/s)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will employ four basebands in FDM mode. Each of Baseband 1,3 and 4 consists of one spectral window of 937.50 MHz width, which is centered to the line frequency of CCH(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2), respectively. Baseband 2 is divided into four windows, whose bandwidths are 234.38 MHz each, and they cover the line frequencies of SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2) and H13CN(3-2).
Toward J1717-337, the absorption line of CCH(1-0) with the FWHM of 5.0 km/s is reported (Ando et al. in prep.), and similar line width of the upper transitions can be expected. Therefore we request the velocity resolution of 0.65 - 0.69 km/s for each line, which is about one seventh of the estimated line width. Owing to the narrowness of absorption lines in Galactic diffuse medium (5.0 km/s in this case), the high velocity resolution mentioned above is indispensable for resolving the velocity component and profile of each line and for measuring the width and depth of it with accuracy.
In terms of spectral window width, it is necessary to cover the frequency range of five hyperfine components of CCH(N=3-2), all of which are required to be resolved in order to derive the optical depth of CCH with a high accuracy. The frequency of CCH(N=3-2, J=5/2-3/2, F=4-3) is 200 MHz off the strongest component, namely CCH(N=3-2, J=7/2-5/2, F=4-3), which is centered in the baseband. We request the bandwidth of Baseband 1 to be 937.50 MHz, which is much wide enough to cover the hyperfine components above, but it is desirable to cover as wide frequency range as possible, because a serendipitious detection of another molecular absorption line can be expected. For Baseband 3 and 4, the same bandwidths as Baseband 1 are needed, because for comparing the profiles of various lines, it is necessary to achieve the same frequency resolution as CCH for all the other lines. The total bandwidth of Baseband 2 is also the same, though it is divided into four windows for the four absorption lines each.
As the frequencies of all the seven species above are covered without multiple tunings, the lines of molecules that have not been detected in the lower transitions (SiO in this case) should also be observed at the same time, because there is possibility to detect the upper transitions, especially with the high sensitivity of ALMA, and the observation time does not increase at any rate. Therefore we request the bandwidths above, which is the best set-up for detecting and analyzing the absorption lines of various molecules.

Since we aim to observe absorption lines toward point sources, which cannot be resolved, high angular resolution is not required. Although we request the angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec, which is required to observe high-declination object 3C111 avoiding compact configurations, the observation of J1717-337 can be conducted with lower angular resolution, i.e. any configuration from C36-1 to C36-6 will do, which corresoponds to the angular resolution of 1.5 to 0.1 arcsec.

In the observation we propose here, we will observe the absorption lines of CCH(3-2), SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2), H13CO+(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2) toward radio-loud quasar J1717-337 in Band 6. We aim to determine excitation temperature of each molecule in Galctic molecular absorption systems, combined with the observations in the lower transitions conducted before (Ando et al. in prep.). The estimation of bandwidth of each line is based on the values of the lower transitions, and we adopted the bandwidth of CCH(1-0) absorption lines, namely 5.0 km/s (Ando et al. in prep.).
For the continuum flux density, we adopted the minimum flux value at 1mm reported in the ALMA Calibrator Source Catalogue. However, since the expected peak flux values vary largely due to the excitation temperatures of the molecules, it is difficult to estimate the peak flux density or S/N accurately. The value used in the sensitivity calculation is the peak flux of CCH(3-2), which we derived with a rotation diagram assuming LTE with the excitation temperature of moderate 8 K, combining the data of CCH(1-0) investigated by Ando et al. (in prep.). We request the line sensitivity of 3.0 mJy over the velocity resolution of ~ 0.65 km/s, in order to constrain the excitation tempratures of most of the molecules below 10 K just in reasonable ~ 25 minutes on-source time, even if the case of non-detection (see details in Table 2 of SJ). This enables us to verify whether the diffuse medium observed toward J1717-337 is in equilibrium with the CMB or not, and to derive column densities of various molecules with a high accuracy, namely with the uncertainty of the factor of 2 or 3. Note that excitation temperature of a certain molecule will be exactly determined if its absorption line is detected, which is sufficiently feasible with the requested RMS.

Since we request to employ four basebands, relatively high data rates (~ 12 MB/s) are expected. The absorption lines of all the seven molecules will be observed without multiple tunings, which is one of the advantages of the observation we propose, but this inevitably increases the data rates. In addition, the high velocity resolution we request, because of the narrow absorption lines (FWHM ~ a few km/s) in Galactic diffuse medium, also causes the higher data rates. We make the data rates as low as possible using spectral avaraging for all the lines, but the data rates we request is essential for observing absorption lines of various molecules with sufficient resolutions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NRAO530
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the absorption lines of the following molecules toward NRAO530, a Galactic molecular absorption systems. The required sensitivity is 3.0 mJy per 1.5" beam and the requested velocity resolution for each molecule is shown in parentheses.
CCH(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) SiO(6-5): USB (0.65 Km/s) H13CO+(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) HCO(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) H13CN(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) CS(5-4): LSB (0.69 km/s) c-HCCCH(3-2): LSB (0.69 km/s)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will employ four basebands in FDM mode. Each of Baseband 1,3 and 4 consists of one spectral window of 937.50 MHz width, which is centered to the line frequency of CCH(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2), respectively. Baseband 2 is divided into four windows, whose bandwidths are 234.38 MHz each, and they cover the line frequencies of SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2) and H13CN(3-2).
Toward NRAO530, the absorption line of CCH(1-0) with the FWHM of 3.5 km/s is reported (Ando et al. in prep.), and similar line width of the upper transitions can be expected. Therefore we request the velocity resolution of 0.65 - 0.69 km/s for each line, which is about one fifth of the estimated line width. Owing to the narrowness of absorption lines in Galactic diffuse medium (3.5 km/s in this case), the high velocity resolution mentioned above is indispensable for resolving the velocity component and profile of each line and for measuring the width and depth of it with accuracy.
In terms of spectral window width, it is necessary to cover the frequency range of five hyperfine components of CCH(N=3-2), all of which are required to be resolved in order to derive the optical depth of CCH with a high accuracy. The frequency of CCH(N=3-2, J=5/2-3/2, F=4-3) is 200 MHz off the strongest component, namely CCH(N=3-2, J=7/2-5/2, F=4-3), which is centered in the baseband. We request the bandwidth of Baseband 1 to be 937.50 MHz, which is much wide enough to cover the hyperfine components above, but it is desirable to cover as wide frequency range as possible, because a serendipitious detection of another molecular absorption line can be expected. For Baseband 3 and 4, the same bandwidths as Baseband 1 are needed, because for comparing the profiles of various lines, it is necessary to achieve the same frequency resolution as CCH for all the other lines. The total bandwidth of Baseband 2 is also the same, though it is divided into four windows for the four absorption lines each.
As the frequencies of all the seven species above are covered without multiple tunings, the lines of molecules that have not been observed in the lower transitions (H13CN in this case) should also be observed at the same time, because there is possibility to detect the upper transitions, especially with the high sensitivity of ALMA, and the observation time does not increase at any rate. Therefore we request the bandwidths above, which is the best set-up for detecting and analyzing the absorption lines of various molecules.

Since we aim to observe absorption lines toward point sources, which cannot be resolved, high angular resolution is not required. Although we request the angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec, which is required to observe high-declination object 3C111 avoiding compact configurations, the observation of NRAO530 can be conducted with lower angular resolution, i.e. any configuration from C36-1 to C36-6 will do, which corresoponds to the angular resolution of 1.5 to 0.1 arcsec.

In the observation we propose here, we will observe the absorption lines of CCH(3-2), SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2), H13CO+(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2) toward radio-loud quasar NRAO530 in Band 6. We aim to determine excitation temperature of each molecule in Galctic molecular absorption systems, combined with the observations in the lower transitions conducted before (Ando et al. in prep., Liszt and Lucas 2001, Lucas and Liszt 1998, 2000a, 2000b, 2002). The estimation of bandwidth of each line is based on the values of the lower transitions, and we adopted the bandwidth of CCH(1-0) absorption lines, namely 3.5 km/s (Ando et al. in prep.).
For the continuum flux density, we adopted the minimum flux value at 1mm reported in the SMA Submillimeter Calibrator List. However, since the expected peak flux values vary largely due to the excitation temperatures of the molecules, it is difficult to estimate the peak flux density or S/N accurately. The value used in the sensitivity calculation is the peak flux of CCH(3-2), which we derived with a rotation diagram assuming LTE with the excitation temperature of moderate 8 K, combining the data of CCH(1-0) investigated by Ando et al. (in prep.). We request the line sensitivity of 3.0 mJy over the velocity resolution of ~ 0.65 km/s, in order to constrain the excitation tempratures of CCH to ~ 6 K and of the other molecules below 20 K just in reasonable ~ 25 minutes on-source time, even if the case of non-detection (see details in Table 2 of SJ). This enables us to verify whether the diffuse medium observed toward NRAO530 is in equilibrium with the CMB or not, to derive the column density of CCH with a high accuracy, namely with the uncertainty of the factor of 2 or 3, and to conduct order-of-magnitude estimates of column densities of the other species. Note that excitation temperature of a certain molecule will be exactly determined if its absorption line is detected, which is sufficiently feasible with the requested RMS.

Since we request to employ four basebands, relatively high data rates (~ 12 MB/s) are expected. The absorption lines of all the seven molecules will be observed without multiple tunings, which is one of the advantages of the observation we propose, but this inevitably increases the data rates. In addition, the high velocity resolution we request, because of the narrow absorption lines (FWHM ~ a few km/s) in Galactic diffuse medium, also causes the higher data rates. We make the data rates as low as possible using spectral avaraging for all the lines, but the data rates we request is essential for observing absorption lines of various molecules with sufficient resolutions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C111
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the absorption lines of the following molecules toward 3C111, a Galactic molecular absorption systems. The required sensitivity is 6.0 mJy per 0.5" beam and the requested velocity resolution for each molecule is shown in parentheses.
CCH(3-2): USB (0.32 km/s) SiO(6-5): USB (0.33 km/s) H13CO+(3-2): USB (0.33 km/s) HCO(3-2): USB (0.33 km/s) H13CN(3-2): USB (0.33 km/s) CS(5-4): LSB (0.35 km/s) c-HCCCH(3-2): LSB (0.35 km/s)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will employ four basebands in FDM mode. Each of Baseband 1,3 and 4 consists of one spectral window of 468.75 MHz width, which is centered to the line frequency of CCH(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2), respectively. Baseband 2 is divided into four spectral windows, whose bandwidths are 117.19 MHz each, and they cover the line frequencies of SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2) and H13CN(3-2).
Toward 3C111, the absorption line of CCH(1-0) with the FWHM of 1.7 km/s is reported (Lucas and Liszt 2000b), and similar line width of the upper transitions can be expected. Therefore we request the velocity resolution of 0.32 - 0.35 km/s for each line, which is about one fifth of the estimated line width. Owing to the narrowness of absorption lines in Galactic diffuse medium (1.7 km/s in this case), the high velocity resolution mentioned above is indispensable for resolving the velocity component and profile of each line and for measuring the width and depth of it with accuracy.
In terms of spectral window width, we chose the width of Baseband 1 because it is necessary to cover the frequency range of five hyperfine components of CCH(N=3-2), all of which are required to be resolved in order to derive the optical depth of CCH with a high accuracy. We request the bandwidth of 468.75 MHz, because the frequency of CCH(N=3-2, J=5/2-3/2, F=4-3) is 200 MHz off the strongest component, namely CCH(N=3-2, J=7/2-5/2, F=4-3), which is centered in the baseband. For the other basebands, the same bandwidths as Baseband 1 are needed, though Baseband 2 is divided into four windows for the four absorption lines each, because for comparing the profiles of various lines, it is necessary to achieve the same frequency resolution as CCH for all the other lines. In addition, it is desireble to sweep as wide frequency range as possible, because we can expect a serendipitious detection of another molecular absorption line.
As the frequencies of all the seven species above are covered without multiple tunings, the lines of molecules that have not been detected in the lower transitions (SiO in this case) should also be observed at the same time, because there is possibility to detect the upper transitions, especially with the high sensitivity of ALMA, and the observation time does not increase at any rate. Therefore we request the bandwidths above, which is the best set-up for detecting and analyzing the absorption lines of various molecules.

We request the beam size of 0.5 arcsec. The target of this observation is a point source, which do not basically require much high angular resolution. However, there is a risk that the observation with a compact configuration would suffer from high shadowing fraction, because of a high declination of 3C111 (+38 deg). In spite of its low elevation, this object is indispensable for the observation proposed here, because it is expected that the strongest absorption will be detected toward 3C111 among the four targets of this observation, or at least the tightest constraints on excitation temperatures of molecules will be given, owing to its high luminosity and strong absorption in lower transitions reported before (Lucas and Liszt 1998, 2000a, 2000b, 2002). Therefore we request that this observation will be conducted avoiding compact configurations, i.e. observation with the configuration C36-3, C36-4, C36-5 or C36-6 is desirable, which coressponds to the angular resolution of 0.5, 0.3, 0.2 and 0.1 arcsec, respectively.

In the observation we propose here, we will observe the absorption lines of CCH(3-2), SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2), H13CO+(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2) toward radio-loud quasar 3C111 in Band 6. We aim to determine excitation temperature of each molecule in Galctic molecular absorption systems, combined with the observations in the lower transitions conducted before (Liszt et al. 2014, Liszt and Lucas 2001, Lucas and Liszt 1998, 2000a, 2000b, 2002). The estimation of bandwidth of each line is based on the values of the lower transitions, and we adopted the bandwidth of CCH(1-0) absorption lines, namely 1.7 km/s (Lucas and Liszt 2000b).
For the continuum flux density, we adopted the minimum flux value at 1mm reported in the SMA Submillimeter Calibrator List. However, since the expected peak flux values vary largely due to the excitation temperatures of the molecules, it is difficult to estimate the peak flux density or S/N accurately. The value used in the sensitivity calculation is the peak flux of CCH(3-2), which we derived with a rotation diagram assuming LTE with the excitation temperature of moderate 8 K, combining the data of CCH(1-0) investigated by Lucas and Liszt (2000b). We request the line sensitivity of 6.0 mJy over the velocity resolution of ~ 0.33 km/s, in order to constrain the excitation tempratures of all the molecules to ~ 3 K just in reasonable ~ 17 minutes on-source time, even if the case of non-detection (see details in Table 2 of SJ). This enables us to verify whether the diffuse medium observed toward 3C111 is in equilibrium with the CMB or not, and to derive column densities of various molecules with a high accuracy, namely with the uncertainty of the factor of 2. Note that excitation temperature of a certain molecule will be exactly determined if its absorption line is detected, which is sufficiently feasible with the requested RMS.

Since we request to employ four basebands, relatively high data rates (~ 12 MB/s) are expected. The absorption lines of all the seven molecules will be observed without multiple tunings, which is one of the advantages of the observation we propose, but this inevitably increases the data rates. In addition, the high velocity resolution we request, because of the narrow absorption lines (FWHM ~ a few km/s) in Galactic diffuse medium, also causes the higher data rates. We make the data rates as low as possible using spectral averaging for all the lines, but the data rates we request is essential for observing absorption lines of various molecules with sufficient resolutions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1625-254
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the absorption lines of the following molecules toward J1625-254, a Galactic molecular absorption systems. The required sensitivity is 3.0 mJy per 1.5" beam and the requested velocity resolution for each molecule is shown in parentheses.
CCH(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) SiO(6-5): USB (0.65 km/s) H13CO+(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) HCO(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) H13CN(3-2): USB (0.65 km/s) CS(5-4): LSB (0.69 km/s) c-HCCCH(3-2): LSB (0.69 km/s)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will employ four basebands in FDM mode. Each of Baseband 1,3 and 4 consists of one spectral window of 937.50 MHz width, which is centered to the line frequency of CCH(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2), respectively. Baseband 2 is divided into four windows, whose bandwidths are 234.38 MHz each, and they cover the line frequencies of SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2) and H13CN(3-2).
Toward J1625-254, the absorption line of CCH(1-0) with the FWHM of 4.5 km/s is reported (Ando et al. in prep.), and similar line width of the upper transitions can be expected. Therefore we request the velocity resolution of 0.65 - 0.69 km/s for each line, which is about one seventh of the estimated line width. Owing to the narrowness of absorption lines in Galactic diffuse medium (4.5 km/s in this case), the high velocity resolution mentioned above is indispensable for resolving the velocity component and profile of each line and for measuring the width and depth of it with accuracy.
In terms of spectral window width, it is necessary to cover the frequency range of five hyperfine components of CCH(N=3-2), all of which are required to be resolved in order to derive the optical depth of CCH with a high accuracy. The frequency of CCH(N=3-2, J=5/2-3/2, F=4-3) is 200 MHz off the strongest component, namely CCH(N=3-2, J=7/2-5/2, F=4-3), which is centered in the baseband. We request the bandwidth of Baseband 1 to be 937.50 MHz, which is much wide enough to cover the hyperfine components above, but it is desirable to cover as wide frequency range as possible, because a serendipitious detection of another molecular absorption line can be expected. For Baseband 3 and 4, the same bandwidths as Baseband 1 are needed, because for comparing the profiles of various lines, it is necessary to achieve the same frequency resolution as CCH for all the other lines. The total bandwidth of Baseband 2 is also the same, though it is divided into four windows for the four absorption lines each.
As the frequencies of all the seven species above are covered without multiple tunings, the lines of molecules that have not been detected in the lower transitions (in this case, SiO, H13CO+, HCO, H13CN and CS) should also be observed at the same time, because there is possibility to detect the upper transitions, especially with the high sensitivity of ALMA, and the observation time does not increase at any rate. Therefore we request the bandwidths above, which is the best set-up for detecting and analyzing the absorption lines of various molecules.

Since we aim to observe absorption lines toward point sources, which cannot be resolved, high angular resolution is not required. Although we request the angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec, which is required to observe high-declination object 3C111 avoiding compact configurations, the observation of J1625-254 can be conducted with lower angular resolution, i.e. any configuration from C36-1 to C36-6 will do, which corresoponds to the angular resolution of 1.5 to 0.1 arcsec.

In the observation we propose here, we will observe the absorption lines of CCH(3-2), SiO(6-5), H13CO+(3-2), HCO(3-2), H13CO+(3-2), CS(5-4) and c-HCCCH(3-2) toward radio-loud quasar J1625-254 in Band 6. We aim to determine excitation temperature of each molecule in Galctic molecular absorption systems, combined with the observations in the lower transitions conducted before (Ando et al. in prep.). The estimation of bandwidth of each line is based on the values of the lower transitions, and we adopted the bandwidth of CCH(1-0) absorption lines, namely 4.5 km/s (Ando et al. in prep.).
For the continuum flux density, we adopted the minimum flux value at 1mm reported in the SMA Submillimeter Calibrator List. However, since the expected peak flux values vary largely due to the excitation temperatures of the molecules, it is difficult to estimate the peak flux density or S/N accurately. The value used in the sensitivity calculation is the peak flux of CCH(3-2), which we derived with a rotation diagram assuming LTE with the excitation temperature of moderate 8 K, combining the data of CCH(1-0) investigated by Ando et al. (in prep.). We request the line sensitivity of 3.0 mJy over the velocity resolution of ~ 0.65 km/s, in order to constrain the excitation tempratures of CCH and c-HCCCH to 4 K and 9 K, respectively, just in reasonable ~ 25 minutes on-source time, even if the case of non-detection (see details in Table 2 of SJ). This enables us to verify whether the diffuse medium observed toward J1625-254 is in equilibrium with the CMB or not, and to derive column densities of the two molecules with a high accuracy, namely with the uncertainty of the factor of 2 or 3. Note that excitation temperature of a certain molecule will be exactly determined if its absorption line is detected, which is sufficiently feasible with the requested RMS.

Since we request to employ four basebands, relatively high data rates (~ 12 MB/s) are expected. The absorption lines of all the seven molecules will be observed without multiple tunings, which is one of the advantages of the observation we propose, but this inevitably increases the data rates. In addition, the high velocity resolution we request, because of the narrow absorption lines (FWHM ~ a few km/s) in Galactic diffuse medium, also causes the higher data rates. We make the data rates as low as possible using spectral avaraging for all the lines, but the data rates we request is essential for observing absorption lines of various molecules with sufficient resolutions.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
In the Galaxy, the detailed nature of ``invisible" diffuse medium that is too cold to be observed in emission is shrouded in mystery, and the unique way to investigate such medium is the observation of its molecular absorption toward bright radio-loud quasars.
Here we propose the Band 6 observation of the upper transitions of C2H, SiO, H13CO+, HCO, H13CN, CS and c-C3H2 in four Galactic molecular absorption systems, which have already been observed in the lower transitions, and three of which are reported to be under PDR-like environments.
With the high sensitivity and velocity resolution of ALMA, we will be able to conduct multi-transition study of absorption lines of the seven species in diffuse medium, and to determine or tightly constrain the excitation temperatures of them for the first time, even in a few hours' observation. This leads us to verify whether PDR-like diffuse medium is in equilibrium with the CMB or not, and to estimate the column densities of various molecules with a high accuracy, as well as to get new insight into understanding the physics and chemistry of such ``invisible" medium.
